New Records: Cleveland's bullpen matched the largest shutout victory margin in club postseason history.
Detroit's shutout was the worst in their playoff history since Game 1 of the 1945 World Series.
Cleveland became the first team in AL postseason history to score five runs before recording an out.
Key Match Events: Lane Thomas hit a three-run homer in his first career postseason swing.
Cleveland's bullpen combined for 4 1/3 hitless innings.
Detroit struck out 13 times and didn't get a runner past first in the final four innings.
David Fry added a two-run double.
Josh Naylor's RBI single contributed to the score.
Pre-Game Insights: The 2,327th meeting between Detroit and Cleveland was the first between the franchises in the postseason.
Tigers manager A.J. Hinch used his bullpen from the start, which backfired.
Post-Match Reflections: Lane Thomas described his home run as 'electric'.
Tigers manager A.J. Hinch commented on the strength of Cleveland's bullpen.
Guardians manager Stephen Vogt praised his team's readiness despite a five-day break.
Tanner Bibee expressed understanding of being pulled early due to the bullpen's strength.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was attended by 33,548 fans at Progressive Field.
The game lasted 2 hours and 50 minutes.
Others: Guardians' RHP Alex Cobb was added to the ALDS roster after recovering from an injury.
Tarik Skubal, the favorite to win the AL Cy Young Award, is expected to start Game 2 for the Tigers.
